learning traditionally fell in two broad categories based on kind of the amount of training data that you had that you
could use to train your models and the sophistication of the deep learning models so supervised learning that's the
type of learning that occurs when you have a large set of training data that's
labeled so if you think about to train a machine learning model to let's say identify flowers the easiest
way to do that is to get thousands of pictures of flowers and label them all have a human person go okay well this
one's a daffodil that one's a rose this one's a chrysanthemum and do that over and over and feed all of that data into
the machine learning model and train it using data so that's supervised learning unsupervised learning is where you also
have a large set of data but it's not labeled and you use the algorithm to try
to find some hidden structure in this data so think about like anomaly detection for instance this third
complimentary approach really has emerged called reinforcement learning or we abbreviate it as RL often RL takes a
different approach and RL actually enables learning complex behaviors without pre labeled data and so that's
what makes RL really powerful so let's just use a really simple example to kind
of give you a high-level understanding of how RL works so let's think about using an algorithm to play pac-man
luckily pac-man only knows how to go up down left right so it's a very easy set
of actions that pac-man can take in each sort of state transition so each state
is basically maybe moving one unit up down left or right or maybe staying
still if he's hiding in a corner that actually makes it pretty easy for the algorithm play also luckily within RL we
typically build a simulation and we train an agent inside of a simulation well for us the game is the simulation
so if we just use the game has the sort of simulation environment we get an easy
way to Train it and to run lots of training kind of runs finally we assign rewards for the
desired behavior that we want so in this case we assign rewards for the more
packed dots pac-man eats or the more points he scores an actuality right

power the power dots so once we assign that reward function we kind of define
it in a so to that environment that we're gonna be testing in we allow the algorithm to
play potentially hundreds or thousands of times and instruct it to maximize its
rewards so in this case maybe it learns to eat fruit while avoiding being eaten
by a ghost so as I mentioned RL
superpower is learning those complex behaviors without requiring labelled training data so RL algorithms can make

have a complex domain space where there's a lot of opportunity for changes
in environments some examples where reinforcement learning has been

level deeper into RL as I mentioned RL is about using rewards to incentivize
behavior and so realistically we we see this happen you know on a daily basis
you know think about the method to use a pet used to train a pet treats are used to incentivize
desired behavior you know training can be around simple actions like just sit or stay or it can extend to more
complicated behaviors like you sometimes see in those dog agility courses where your pets are crawling through tunnels
and jumping over hurdles and weaving through poles reinforcement learning as
I mentioned is this branch of machine learning that's interested in the creation of a model that can be used by
an agent to choose which actions to take in and specific environment in order to
achieve a goal so in the AWS deep racer case we can think about each of these
things and how they apply so we're trying to build and train a model online our agent is the virtual car running in
the simulator the actions that can take is the throttle or the left/right
steering the environment is essentially where it is on the track and the goal is
to complete the track in the lowest amount of time so how does learning
happen so as deep racer drives around the track you know it's taking basically
pictures of the track in front of it so that cameras running at about 10 to 15 FPS and the simulated racetrack in even
in the virtual simulator we're simulating the car looking at the front of the track in the same manner that the
physical car would so that we get a good what's called domain transfer so the
pictures that the car takes you know at you know that 10 FPS or whatever is effectively representations of the state
of the environment and the agent uses the state and the model to determine which action to choose right so maybe
ten times a second the model is kind of evaluating the environment and whether
it should you know turn slight right turn full right go straight turn slight left or full left etc so initially the
untrained model is going to choose actions at random to explore the environment but over time it will notice
which actions lead to better outcomes which are of course dependent upon the state it then starts exploit
this knowledge to repeatedly take the action that will lead to the best outcome based on that particular state
now you determine how soon your model sort of balances between exploiting the
knowledge that it's gained and just exploring if you exploit too soon you might forego
finding a better action like a more optimal path to your solution but but if
you explore too long your model might take a very long time to train because it might it might never start to or
it'll it'll take a long time before it starts to exploit the knowledge that it already has but how does your model know
the best outcome whoops how does your model know the best outcome for an
action the model will choose the action it thinks will lead to the outcome with the highest reward and this is where
that reward function comes in that we talked about so for instance a reward function for the AWS deep racer could
provide rewards for staying close to the center line and maybe decrease rewards
exponentially as you move away from the center line during each state evaluation
or it could give a reward for smooth steering so maybe if you you know if
you're turning a lot and weaving that's gonna slow you down so maybe you're gonna sort of balance a reward function
to provide rewards based on maybe a combination of factors like smooth steering and staying close to the center
line so when you look at deep racer we'll give you a couple template reward files and these are really simple
they're just Python code probably like 15 to 20 lines of code super simple for
developers of almost any skill level to kind of take a look at and read and then start tweaking those reward functions so
after each action the simulator will use the reward function to quantify how good
or bad and outcome is and calculate the reward for the outcome so one such state
where it work where it evaluates the reward for a specific action is called a
step and then there's a set of steps that happen from the start state where
we spawn the car in the virtual simulator to the point where it's a terminal State in other words if the car
goes too far off the track or finishes a lap we call that series of steps and episode and so after a set
number of episodes the model will use the experience obtained to kind of
restart the process and start to exploit the knowledge that it's already gained you know models could have a large
number of episodes in order to be successful for driving around the track at least as we've seen with deep racer
anywhere from several hundred to a thousand or more episodes and the beauty of it is this is all happening online in
a simulator so it's not like you have to wait for a car or walk around and pick up a car and put it back on the track
all of this happens online virtually so once your model is trained you'll
basically have this function which we call a value function that knows what the cumulative reward is for all actions
in a state simply selecting the action with the highest reward will should give
the best outcome and this mapping from state to an action is called the policy function so this works when you can
quantify every possible kind of state action reward set but you know just
build like a lookup table but for many RL domains autonomous driving included you can't explore every state action
combination and so what do you do like how how do you know the reward value that's associated with each action
that's where you use a function or you approximate the value function so I'm
not going to go into approximating the value function but that's where neural networks and deep reinforcement learning
kind of come into play and that's actually what's used on deep racer so if you're interested in that definitely
encourage you to you know make some time on your own and explore value functions
and and approximations for value functions and how they relate to you know policy networks okay
